title: derek-mackay-set-share-2-2m-msp-golden-goodbyes
story: Nine MSPs who failed to get re-elected earlier this month and  who stood down of their own accord, will be paid controversial ldquoresettlement grants to help them adjust to le after Holyrood.All will get at least pound,, the equivalent of half a yearrsquos salary, but those with more than six years service get extra pro rata, up to a full yearrsquos salary of pound,.The first pound, of the lump sum, which is paid automatically by the Scottish Parliament under a  law, is tax free.The grants include pound, payable to Mr Mackay despite him vanishing from the parliament in February  after he resigned for pestering a -year-old schoolboy with sleazy texts.:Absentee MSP Derek Mackay claims yet more Holyrood expensesMr Mackay, the former SNP MSP for Renfrewshire North and West, has already received a separate payment of pound, just for losing ministerial office, in spite of the circumstances.Resettlement grants are meant to help "with the cost of adjusting to non-parliamentary le", and the only qualication is being an MSP immediately before a Holyrood election and not being one after it.No account is taken of personal wealth.Former Scottish Tory leader Ruth Davidson, who is headed for a pound-a-day seat in the House of Lords and recently landed an pound,-a-year jobas a non-executive director of insurer Royal London, is due a grant of pound, after ten years as an MSP.Former SNP childrenrsquos minister Mark McDonald, who quit over a sleaze scandal in , is due to get pound, for eight years continuous service.All of Holyroodrsquos parties have MSPs who will share in the pay-outs.Sixteen former SNP MSPs will collect more than pound, between them, while  former Labour MSPs are together in line for pound,, and ten former Tory MSPs will share pound,.Because he lost his seat in , then ed to Holyrood in , former Liberal Democrat MSP Mike Rumbles is entitled to a second grant of pound, after previously qualying for pound,.Four former cabinet secretaries - Aileen Campbell, Roseanna Cunningham, Jeane Freeman and Mike Russell - will also get grants of pound, each later in the summer for loss of ministerial office.All except Ms Freeman are due to receive maximum resettlement grants of pound,.Deputy presiding officer Linda Fabiani is also entitled to a special grant for losing that post of pound,, which when added to her maximum MSP pay-off gives her a total of pound,.:SNP attack Ruth Davidson for letting down people of ScotlandThe grants for loss of special offices are in addition to the pound.m worth of golden goodbyes.After the  election, the final bill for voluntary leavers and election losers was pound,,, and after  it was pound,,.The Taxpayers Alliance recently said voters would be ldquooutraged" at MSPs getting such generous sums and urged the SNP to change the law to ease the burden on taxpayers.The Scottish Parliament said: "Resettlement grants are paid in accordance with the Scottish Parliamentary Pensions Act ," adding the final cost would be in its next annual accounts.

title: watch-hares-breeding-golden-eagles-make-comeback-orkney-almost-40-years
story: From then the hares only had the odd great skua to be concerned about until a resident pair of white-tailed eagles set up home near the Dwarfie Stane six years ago. Now they have golden eagles to contend having ed to make their home at Hoy on Orkney and are breeding once again.Earlier this year local staff with animal welfare charity RSPB Scotland were delighted to spot a pair nesting at the organisationrsquos nature reserve in Hoy and can confirm that they now have chicks.The majestic pair have been seen flying about as they forage.The golden eagle used to be a common sight and bred across Orkney but persecution by humans through habitat loss and shooting meant just a single pair was left by  in Hoy.Orkney had to wait  years until  to see theof breeding golden eagles.This pair had a long and successful partnership in Hoy raising many chicks together until one of the adults died in the winter of .As golden eagles pair for le the surviving eagle continued toto Hoy for three years but there were no further nesting attempts.:Police investigate "disgraceful" theft of golden eagle eggs in HighlandsBut now a new pair have arrived and RSPB Scotland staff have been keeping a watchful eye on the new pair to see how they are faring.As golden eagles are very sensitive to disturbance the location of the nest is not being disclosed, and the number of chicks is not known as those watching it having been keeping a safe distance away.The species typically has one or two chicks at a time, so the local team say they are looking forward to when the young fledge to see how many emerge.Credit: Christine HallLee Shields, RSPB Scotlandrsquos Hoy warden, said ldquoIt is wonderful to see these magnicent eaglesto Orkney and wersquore delighted that they are nesting in Hoy. Golden eagles are one of the most iconic birds in Scotland and they have been missing here for too long. ldquoWe want to give these birds the best chance of success which is why itrsquos so important to not reveal where the nest is. It is an inspiring sight to see the male and female soaring over the Hoy hills, and wersquore eagerly awaiting finding out how many chicks they have.ldquoThis golden eagle pair are at an early stage of their breeding le and as they are long-lived birds we hope not only that they will be as successful as their predecessors, but that they are the beginning of this species re-establishing itself in Orkney. These birds are an integral part of Orkneyrsquos history and with this pair and their young wersquore keeping our fingers crossed we can look forward to them being part of its future once again. RSPB Scotland say Hoy appears to be the go to place for ing eagles to breed in Orkney, probably due to the terrain in uninhabited areas of the island being well suited for them.Back in , Orkneyrsquos first white-tailed eagle chicks for over  years hatched in Hoy.Then RSPB Scotland ran Eaglewatch events to allow people to catch a glimpse of the birds but given the heightened sensitivity of golden eagles and as the white-tailed eagles have not bred this year, the bird charity is not repeating that. Golden eagles are one of the largest birds in Scotlandn with a lespan typicallly of over  years. They are more than twice the size of a buzzard, with a wingspan of between six and seven-and-a-half feet.All of the UKrsquos breeding golden eagles are found in Scotland, with the most recent national survey in  putting their numbers at just  pairs.The RSPB say that a number of lines of evidence indicat that illegal persecution of eagles, principally associated with grouse moor management in the central and eastern Highlands, is the most severe constraint on Scottish golden eagles.It says the highest national priority for the conservation and management of golden eagles in Scotland is to tackle persecution in those areas where it still persists.A secondary national priority for restorative management is to promote "greater availability of live prey in parts of the western Highlands, potentially through changes in the management of deer and sheep".A pair of sea eagles are also nesting on RSPB Scotlandrsquos Hoy nature reserve.When they arrived in , it was the first time these birds had attempted to breed in Orkney since .Sea eagles have a long history in Orkney. The Bronze Age burial tomb at Isbister, South Ronaldsay famously contains their bones, while a Pictish symbol stone found at the Knowe of Burrian, Harray, features a beautully carved bird.

title: covid-19-pregnant-mothers-relief-vaccine-wait
story: The -year-old, who is  weeks pregnant with her second child, said she was more concerned about the risks of the virus than any posed by the vaccine. Those fears had increased as her pregnancy progressed.ldquoI had a chat with my consultant and it was more about, how can we hurry this up, she said.Pregnant women are not currently being prioritised for vaccines with appointments based on age and clinical risk group.However, there has been calls for this to change on account of growing evidence that Covid- can lead to complications for both mother and baby, including stillbirth or premature delivery.: Cautious optimism for Glasgow as virus shows signs of slowdownDr Sarah Stock, a leading Scots obstetrician, said the current recommendations are based on the best available evidence, but added women should be offered prompt appointments at centres which offer ldquoappropriate vaccines.The Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationhas said it is preferable for pregnant women in the UK to be offered the Pfizer or Moderna vaccines because their safety is backed by a US trial involving , women. There is no evidence to suggest other vaccines are unsafe for pregnant women but studies are ongoing.Data on uptake rates amongst pregnant women is not available yet in Scotland but there have been reports of women continuing to be advised not to have vaccines by midwives.The UKrsquos first Covid- vaccine study for pregnant women is about to get under way at  hospital sites, including Edinburgh where about  womenwill be given the Pfizer BioNTech vaccine or a placebo.: Pioneering Scots study could lead to new treatments for CovidMs Mulholland, who is due to give birth to her second child on July , said she had no reservations about coming forward for her jag but said she would only have accepted the Pfizer or Moderna vaccines.ldquoI had tears in my eyes, said Ms Mullholland, who is married to Stephen, , and has a two-year-oldson Xavier.ldquoI actually didnrsquot have any concerns. I can only speak for myself, but I think when the JCVI said it was fine for pregnant women to get the vaccine, routinely, I felt really relieved.ldquoI am consultant led because Irsquom having a section and I had a quick chat with her but it was more, how can we hurry this up rather than whether I should have it. She was very supportive and there was no qualms in her mind.ldquoFor me, there was more and more evidence that especially when you are getting into your third trimester, you are more likely to have severe complications. I feel breathless all the time as it is, because Irsquom a bit anaemic so I did not fancy also having a respiratory illness.ldquoTherersquos also a higher chance of premature birth. Irsquom having a section this time, so I will be in hospital for at least two nights so there is the risk of hospital acquired infection, said Ms Mulholland, who lives in Kilmacolm in Renfrewshire.ldquoThen of course, being in the Glasgow area, itrsquos in the backdrop of rising cases and my wee one is at nursery, so itrsquos not like I can shield. So for me I was really relieved. I do take other vaccines, like the flu jag.Dr Stock, who is an honorary consultant in maternal and fetal medicine at Edinburgh University, said it was understandable that women might feel some anxiety about receiving a newer vaccine.She said: ldquoI think itrsquos entirely understandable that you might have questions about taking any medication in pregnancy.ldquoThere is accumulating real world evidence that the vaccine is safe in pregnancy.ldquoThere is no evidence it affects fertility or breastfeeding. What we do have evidence of is that Covid- can be serious in pregnancy. We know that pregnant women can become unwell and it can cause complications in the baby such as premature birth.ldquoSome women might be at higher risk with underlying conditions or at higher risk of exposure to Covid-.: Covid vaccination appointments extended to - age groupldquoThe data that we have accumulating mainly comes from the States andthat relates to Pfizer and Moderna vaccines.ldquoHowever, pregnant women havehad the AstraZeneca vaccine and certainly the advice is thatthey have had their first dose of AZ to continue with that.ldquoIf you are going along with your age grouping, you should be directed to centres where they have the Pfizer vaccines and I thinkyour centre doesnrsquot, we can re-arrange the appointment for you.She said the data had also been reassuring for women who had taken part in trials, unaware they were pregnant.

title: two-child-benefit-cap-clear-breach-human-rights-says-scots-commissioner
story: The devolved nations Childrens Commissionershave jointly written to Work and Pensions Secretary Therese Coffey, claiming that the policy, which prevents families from claiming some benefits payments for their third and subsequent children, is a ldquoclear breach of childrenrsquos human rights.:Iain Macwhirter: Sturgeon could be caught in the Cummings crossfireThe three commissionersstate that the rule breaches youngstersrsquo right to an adequate standard of living and is contributing to a rising gap in poverty levels between families with three or more children and smaller households.The letter, from Bruce Adamson, the Children and Young Peoplersquos Commissioner for Scotland and his Welsh and Northern Irish counterparts, Sally Holland and Koulla Yiasouma, also argues that the policy has a disproportionate impact on some minority faith and ethnic communities ndash where larger families are more common ndash as well as in Northern Ireland, where families tend to be larger than the rest of the UK.Mr Adamson, who will address MPs on the Parliamentrsquos Work and Pensions Committee on Wednesday, said that living in poverty could impact on ldquoevery aspect of a childrsquos le.Speaking ahead of that meeting, he said: ldquoWith more than a quarter of a million children affected, poverty is the most signicant human rights issue facing children in Scotland.ldquoLiving in poverty affects every aspect of a childrsquos le, including their educational attainment and mental and physical health.He recalled that Philip Alson, the UN special rapporteur on poverty and human rights, had heard directly from youngsters during a visit to Scotland in , saying children told him of the ldquoserious impact that poverty is having on their human rights.But Mr Adamson added: ldquoNow, after over a year of the Covid- pandemic, the situation for children in Scotland has become much worse.He continued: ldquoThe Scottish Government has taken some action to reduce the number of children in poverty including rolling out the Scottish Child Payment during the pandemic, however, I remain concerned that childrenrsquos rights are continuing to be breached in Scotland by the two-child limit on child tax credit and universal credit.ldquoThat is why we have taken the step of writing to the UK Government to urge that this policy is reversed.Mr Adamson said while he and the commissioners in Wales and Northern Ireland would hold the ministers there to account, the devolved administrations ldquocan only go so far in their efforts to ensure children and their families get the support they are entitled to while this discriminatory policy also remains in force at a UK level.He added: ldquoWith the focus in the Queenrsquos speech in May  on levelling up, there can be no excuse for continuing to breach childrenrsquos rights through this discriminatory policy that will continue to harm and prevent children and families from moving beyond the impact of the global pandemic.:Ian McConnell: Is Boris Johnson Australia trade deal more trouble than it is worth A UK Government spokesman said: ldquoWe are committed to supporting families that are most in need and the latest figures show that the percentage of children in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland living in absolute poverty has actually fallen since .ldquoFour out of five households across the UK have two or fewer children, and this policy ensures fairness by asking families in receipt of benefits to make the same financial choices as people who support themselves solely through work.ldquoThere are also careful exemptions and safeguards in place to protect people in the most vulnerable circumstances.

title: cummings-chicken-pox-style-parties-considered-method-creating-herd-immunity-covid
story: Dominic Cummings, the Prime Ministers former senior aide, made the claim during an evidence session of theScience and Technology Committee and Health and Social Care Committee this morning.He claimed that Mark Sedwill, former head of the Civil Service and Cabinet Secretary until June last year,suggested telling people they should hold old-fashioned "chicken pox parties" to generate herd immunity against coronavirus.He said Mr Sedwill wanted Boris Johnson to go on television and tell people to hold covid-spreading parties, explaining:"The Cabinet Secretary said Prime Minister, you should go on TV tomorrow and explain to people the herd immunity plan, and that its like the old chicken pox parties. We need people to get this disease, because thats how we get herd immunity by September."Mr Cummings said he told Mr Sedwill to "stop using this chickenpox analogy", while another adviser explained it was "because chickenpox is not spreading exponentially and killing hundreds of thousandsof people."The former aide continued: "You couldsense in the whole room there was this kind of shock."Mr Cummings also told MPs of a "surreal" day in Downing Street, March  , when he had urged Boris Johnson to advise the public to self-isolate immediatelythey were unwell.He said the plans were "derailed" after Donald Trump requested the UKs help in a bombing campaign in the Middle East, and Carrie Symonds, the Prime Ministers fiancee, was "going crackers" about a news story featuring her, Mr Johnson and their dog Dilyn.Mr Cummings said: "The day started off with us thinking [it] is going to be all about Covid and whether or not announced the household quarantine."We then got completely derailed because in the morning of the th suddenlythe national security people came in and said Trump wants us to join a bombing campaign in the Middle East tonightand we need to start having meetings about that through the day with Cobra as well."That day was, on Covid, completely disrupted because you have these two parallel sets of meetings."You have the national security people running in and out talking about are we going to bomb the Middle East, and we had the COBRA meetings being delayed and whatnot, as we were trying to figure out are we going to do household quarantine."He continued: "Then...it sounds so surreal I couldnt possibly be true...That day the Times had run a huge story about the Prime Minister and his girlfriend and their dog, and the Prime Ministers girlfriend was going completely crackers about this story and demanding that the press office deal with that."Mr Cummings said there was an "insane situation" in No., explaining: "Part of the building was sayingAre we going to bomb Iraq , part of the building was arguing about whether or not were going to do quarantine or not do quarantine, Prime Minister has his girlfriend going crackers about something completely trivial..."

title: hms hood to be commemorated in orkney
story: A series of online events will mark the th anniversary of the sinking of one of the UK#s most famous naval vessels.Another Orkney Production’sannual event Celebrating Scapa Flow kicks off, this Friday evening, online. This year commemorate HMS Hood with an online programme on May  and , hosted in conjunction with the Orkney International Science Festival.Shortly before midnight on May , , HMS Hood weighed anchor and sailed out of Scapa Flow through Hoxa Sound to patrol the waters south of Iceland and prevent Germany’s largest battleship, Bismarck, from reaching the North Atlantic.On May , a battle in the Denmark Strait resulted in the loss of HMS Hood. She sank within minutes of being hit, with the loss of , lives. Only three of her ,-strong crew survived.The weekend#s events will be broadcast online on the Orkney International Science Festival Youtube channel. The programme begins this evening at pm with HMS Hood, Last of her Kind — a discussion involving Captain Christ Smith, Cdr William Sutherland Cdr David Hobbs and Rob White. title: mcarthur calls for island proofed covid recovery
story: In the wake of the announcement of a new cabinet secretary for COVID recovery, Orkney MSP Liam McArthur has called for Scotland#s post-pandemic rehabilitation plan to be #island-proofed#.Mr McArthur has joined Shetland MSP Beatrice Wishart in penning a letter to the new cabinet secretary, John Swinney, appealing for the islands to be “front and centre of Scottish Government thinking”.This joint letter comes ahead of a cross party steering group due to be meet next week.The isles MSPs have shared the frustration of many of their constituents who feel that Orkney and Shetland were often seen as an “afterthought” in Scottish Government decision making processes.In the letter, the MSPs pointed to repeated announcements which updated central belt communities while neglecting to mention the dferences in restrictions for the islands.“Throughout the pandemic, there has been a frustration in the communities we represent that island needs have appeared to be an afterthought in Scottish Government decision making processes,# they wrote to Mr Swinney.#Announcements have been made with a wealth of detail about restrictions affecting central belt communities, while failing to include any mention of important dferences for island communities working under dferent rules.“This has often created confusion, not helped by the recent consultation on the easing of restrictions in the islands which was ill-conceived, poorly constructed and the responses ultimately ignored by the government.“As we look ahead to dealing with the impacts of the pandemic and shaping the recovery, it is important that this work fully reflects the islands dimension. We seek assurances, therefore, that  steps will be taken to ensure that this happens. Close collaboration with locally elected representatives, including the island authorities, will be important but we would encourage you and your officials to look at other ways of making sure this happens from the outset.“Needless to say, we would be happy to meet with you to discuss this matter in more detail.  Meantime, we wish you well in the substantial task that lies ahead and stand ready to assist, particularly in ensuring the needs of our islands are front and centre of government thinking.“We look forward to hearing from you in due course.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orkney folk urged to join garden mammal survey
story: Summer is approaching and you may have spotted a furry friend or two roaming about your garden in recent weeks.If you have, People#s Trust for Endangered Speciesis keen to hear from you as it launches its wildle Living with Mammals survey for .PTES saw record-breaking numbers of volunteers taking part last year, thanks to more people being at home and having the time to watch wildle in their gardens and or nearby green spaces. The result was a huge increase in the number of mammal sightings, from hazel dormice on bird feeders to hedgehogs snuffling in gardens after dark.The trust believes that participation sparked a newfound appreciation, love and interest in nature for many, in all corners of the country.PTES is keen to build on this positive relationship with nature made during the past year and is asking folk to look out for and record sightings and signs of wild mammalsin their gardens or local green spaces. title: road surface dressing delayed by weather
story: newsRoad surface dressing delayed by weatherMay ,  at : pmSurface dressing work which was due to take place in Firth today was postponed due to cold weather, Orkney Islands Council has advised.According to OIC, the work on Holland Road will have to wait until warmer, drier weather s to the county.Surface dressing requires higher road surface temperatures for the materials to bed in properly — something the current cold rainy spell could compromise.The council has advised that, at this stage, the works will be delayed until at least next Tuesday. This will have a knock-on effect on other works planned for that week at Puldrite Road in Rendall, Arwick Road in Evie, Georth Road in Evie, Brough Road in Birsay, Ravie Hill Road in Birsay, and Hundland Road in Birsay.Members of the public affected are advised to check the council website www.orkney.gov.uk news.htm for updates and keep an eye on the the OIC Updates Facebook page.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: safety first as shops reopen
story: For the latest on government guidance, retailers should visit gov.uk workingsafelyThe curtain goes up again at Stephen Joseph Theatre on May  while Eat Me Cafe, in the bar area, and a gt shop, in the foyer, will also reopen.“We were open for nearly six months of last year. We did a huge amount of work including introducing a one-way system, social distancing measures and putting down markers,” said theatre manager Paul Baines. “One of the biggest challenges was getting people in and out safely.“We have to ensure the measures are genuine and effective and they are visible. Visible reassurance is important for customer confidence.“It is a juggling act because you have to balance creating a too clinical atmosphere with offering a unique theatre experience.”The theatre has been awarded the VisitEngland We’re Good to Go industry standard mark, signying that it adheres to government and public health COVID- guidance, also approved by UK Theatre Seat Safety.Alongside familiar COVID- safety measures, Rosie Fraser has introduced a new service called “Silent Treatment”.“We love a good chat but we also understand some people prefer not to,” said Rosie, whose beauty salon opened in .“Clients can see the service as soon as they look at the online booking menu and add it with whatever treatments they are having.“We still carry out a full consultation and then let them just relax.”Also in place are bespoke engraved screens between stations, extra time for cleaning, screening forms for track and trace, PPE and sanitising measures. Rosie emphasises that it is safety with style! Members of the seven-strong team are carrying out rapid COVID- tests at home thanks to the UK Government asymptomatic testing initiative.“We have exciting plans for this year in expanding. COVID- and lockdown has reaffirmed how much people need care and pampering to feel good.”Investment has helped Fish City in Belfast continue operating. The award-winning seafood restaurant extended its seating, installed outdoor heating and started a delivery service. Since reopening for outdoor dining, it has been doing a brisk trade bolstered by confidence in the vaccine programme. Reopening indoors is scheduled to start on May .“We created a dining room upstairs with a completely dferent feel,” said John, who owns the restaurant with his we Grainne. Safety processes include a digital thermometer mounted at the door which all staff and customers are required to pass before entering. Anyone recording a high temperature is refused admission.Hand sanitisers are also available. Kitchen and front of house staff are required to wear masks and wash their hands regularly. Tables and chairs are cleaned rigorously after every diner. The restaurant’s commitment to the safety is also seen in its recognition as COVID- Compliant by Tourism NI.“If I could do cartwheels, I would” is one retail chief’s response to welcoming the public back.“When we saw the first trickle of people coming back last month, it was lovely,” enthused village location manager Meurig Jones. “Portmeirion needs people here.“It’s lovely but it isn’t what it should be without people appreciating it. It’s easier this year in that it was such a new thing when we opened in July.“We had to do a lot of work to train the staff into a new way of working. We’re constantly improving and we’re learning as we go on.”App orders and one-way systems will ensure ongoing safety. Outside seating, pods and marquee are also available. Misting machines, meanwhile, will keep hotels “squeaky clean – safe for staff and guests”.Meurig added: “There’s hand sanitiser outside every shop and we ask people to wear masks indoors, but not outside.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Sir Mick JaggerMusical legends including Sir Mick Jagger and Sting are among those supporting a fundraising concert in memory of a teenager who died after being diagnosed with a brain tumour.Daniel Caplan died in December aged  after being diagnosed with a DIPG tumour, an aggressive form of tumour with no cure, in May last year.His fellow pupils at Hutchesonsrsquo Grammar School in Glasgow have organised an online concert covering chart hits from the s to the present and hope to raise pound, for the Funding Neuro charity, which funds research into brain tumours and in particular DIPG tumours.Sir Mick, Sting and other singers including Emeli Sande have lent their support to the Doing it for Daniel concert by recording video messages for the event, which will air online at pm on Thursday. vw,vw,px, px"Daniel died in December last year In his message, Sir Mick says: ldquoHi, itrsquos Mick Jagger here, I would like to wish everyone at Hutchesonsrsquo all the best for your concert.I hope you enjoy the music, bye.Sting says: ldquoI would like to introduce two of my songs being performed tonight, Fields Of Gold and Shape Of My Heart. Take it away.Danielrsquos mother Alison described her sonrsquos death as ldquoabsolutely shattering and said she is surprised more progress has not been made in brain tumour research.She told BBC Breakfast: ldquoYoursquore literally told on the day of the news of the biopsy that your child will die, and they will probably die within months and there is no treatment plan available.ldquoTo watch your child die in that way was absolutely shattering because as a mother you want to do everything you can for your children and I couldnrsquot save him.ldquoNo-one could save him and I couldnrsquot believe that decades had gone by and so little progress had been made in the field of brain tumours.ldquoIrsquove never actually met anyone as full of fun and le as Daniel, he wanted to do well in le, he loved music, he loved football, he loved socialising with his friends, he loved his dog Alfie, he just was a boy who was meant to be alive.In her message for the concert, Sande says: ldquoItrsquos me Emeli Sande, Irsquom sending you lots of love and lots support for such a special important evening. vw,vw,px, px"Emeli Sande has also sent a message of support Singer Fiona Meighan, , an S pupil, said: ldquoDue to Covid restrictions we havenrsquot been able to hold the usual fundraising events in school. Charity and fundraising have always been a huge part of the ethos at Hutchesonsrsquo, but this year supporting Funding Neuro has been incredibly important for a huge number of us, because of Daniel.ldquoI was really excited to perform in the concert and to support such a worthwhile cause and I was blown away by the support we received from all the music artists, including Sting and Sir Mick Jagger.ldquoIt gave us all a real boost and we hope their support will raise awareness of the need for more research into DIPG.Funding Neuro needs to raise pound. million for a treatment trial led by Professor Steven Gill for  children with DIPG tumours, pound million of which has already been raised.Broadcast students from the University of the West of Scotland filmed and edited the performances.David Mulligan, chief executive of Funding Neuro, said % of the funds raised from the concert will be used to finance Prof Gillrsquos clinical trial.Danielrsquos parents are also in the process of setting up the Doing It For Daniel Foundation, which will offer gts and holiday breaks to children diagnosed with cancer.Tickets for the event can be bought at https:hutchesons.ticketco.events uk en e doing-it-for-daniel-concert or on the Funding Neuro page on the school website https:www.hutchesons.org our-school community school-charities funding-neuro .copy -. support as possible during these challenging times.Dominic Cummings quizzed by MPsDominic Cummings has described chaos in Downing Street in the days leading up to the first Covid lockdown, with a ldquoscene from Independence Day and the Prime Ministerrsquos fiancee Carrie Symonds going ldquocompletely crackers over press coverage of her dog Dilyn.Boris Johnsonrsquos former chief adviser told MPs the country should have locked down the first week of March  at the latest but the ldquoofficial logic even on March  was that this would only cause a peak of the virus later on.He claimed the Governmentrsquos delay in locking down and lack of action plan was similar to  disaster film Independence Day in which the US is devastated by a surprise alien invasion, and compared his data expert colleague Ben Warner to Jeff Goldblumrsquos scientist in the film whose warnings were ignored.He told the committee of MPs the situation at the time was: ldquoThis is like a scene from Independence Day with Jeff Goldblum saying, lsquothe aliens are here and your whole plan is broken, and you need a new planrsquo.Mr Cummings said: ldquoOne of the critical things that was completely wrong in the whole official thinking, in Sage and in the Department of Health in February March was first of all the British public will not accept a lockdown, secondly, the British public will not accept what was thought of as a kind of East Asian style track and trace type system, and the infringement of liberty around that.ldquoThose two assumptions were completely central to the official plan and were both obviously completely wrong.Mr Cummings said he felt ldquomounting panic about the response and was pushing on March  and  for the Government to announce that iniduals should stay at homethey had symptoms and households should quarantine.But he said there was ldquopush back from within the system and ldquome and others were realising at this point the system is basically delaying announcing all of these things because therersquos not a proper plan in place.He added: ldquoAs far as I could tell from Sage, and as far as the minutes show, the fundamental assumption remained we canrsquot do lockdown, we canrsquot do suppression, because it just means a second peak.Mr Cummings said March  was a ldquocompletely surreal day, starting with him texting the Prime Minister at .am saying: ldquoWersquove got big problems coming.ldquoThe Cabinet Office is terryingly s***, no plans, totally behind the pace, we must announce today, not next week, lsquo you feel ill with cold or flu stay at homersquo.ldquoSome around the system wanted to delay because they havenrsquot done the work.ldquoWe must force the pace, wersquore looking at  to , deaths between optimistic and pessimistic scenarios.He said the day got derailed from dealing with Covid because in the morning ldquosuddenly, the national security people came in and said lsquoTrump wants us to join a bombing campaign in the Middle East tonightrsquohellip and we need to start having meetings about that through the day with Cobra as well. vw,vw,px, px"Mr Cummings said a story about Boris Johnsonrsquos fiancee Carrie Symonds and dog Dilyn had been printed ldquoSo everything to do with Cobra that day on Covid was completely disrupted because you had these two parallel sets of meetings, you had the national security people running in and out talking about lsquoare we going to bomb the Middle East rsquohellip And then to add to it, it sounds so surreal it couldnrsquot possibly be true, that day The Times had run a huge story about the Prime Minister and his girlfriend and their dog, and the Prime Ministerrsquos girlfriend was going completely crackers about this story and demanding that the press office deal with that.ldquoSo, we have this sort of completely insane situation in which part of the building was saying, lsquoare we going to bomb Iraq rsquo, part of the building was arguing about whether or not wersquore going to do quarantine or not do quarantine, the Prime Minister has his girlfriend going crackers about something completely trivial.ldquoAnd you have all these meetings kind of going on through the course of the th.He said he had a meeting with advisers Ben and Marc Warner around pm ldquowhen they kind of hit the total panic button with me and they said, lsquowersquore looking at all this data, wersquore looking at all of these graphs, wersquore heading for a total catastrophe and we need to have Plan Brsquo.Mr Cummings said that on the evening of March  it was realised that a meeting would need to be held with Mr Johnson to explain ldquowersquore going to have to ditch the whole official plan, wersquore heading for the biggest disaster this country has seen since .Mr Cummings has tweeted a picture from this evening, which he called the ldquofirst sketch of Plan B, PM study, Fri   eve ndash shown PM Sat  .He said the ldquosecond most powerful official in the country at the time, Helen MacNamara, who was deputy cabinet secretary, walked into the room during the meeting with Ben Warner on March  and said: ldquoIrsquove just been talking to the official Mark Sweeney who is in charge of co-ordinating with the Department of Health. He said, quote, lsquoIrsquove been told for years that there was a whole plan for this. There is no plan. Wersquore in huge troublersquo. vw,vw,px, px"Dominic Cummings during the evidence session to the joint inquiry of the Commons Health and Social Care and Science and Technology committees Mr Cummings said she told him: ldquoI think we are absolutely f*****, I think this country is headed for disaster, I think wersquore going to kill thousands of people.Mr Cummings said he told her: ldquoI think yoursquore right. I think it is a disaster.He said that on March , the Prime Minister was told: ldquoYou are going to have to lock down.But Mr Cummings added: ldquoBut there is no lockdown plan. Sage havenrsquot modelled it, DH donrsquot have a plan, we are going to have to figure out and hack together a lockdown plan.He added: ldquoThis is like a scene from Independence Day with Jeff Goldblum saying, lsquothe aliens are here and your whole plan is broken, and you need a new planrsquohellip that is what the scene was like that morning, with Ben Warner in the Jeff Goldblum role.ldquoHe took the Prime Minister through all the graphs, and through the NHS graphs, and showed him that the system is thinking this is all weeks and weeks and awayhellip but this is all completely wronghellip The NHS is going to be smashed in weeks.Mr Cummings said it was a ldquohuge failure on his own part that he did not push harder for an earlier lockdown.He said: ldquoI bitterly regret that I didnrsquot kind of hit the emergency panic button earlier than I did.ldquoI think, in retrospect, therersquos no doubt that I was wrong not to.He said he was ldquoincredibly frightened to say the official plan was wrong in case he himself was wrong.copy -. story: Shetland Islands Council is inviting responses to an online survey on tackling climate change.The council’s recently formed Climate Change Programme focuses on reducing Shetland’s waste production and greenhouse gas emissions.To help gather views and identy emerging issues, local householders and businesses are asked to respond to an online survey, the results of which will feed into a “Net Zero” future plan for Shetland.The online survey will mark the start of an ongoing local “climate conversation” covering key topics such as energy supply, transport, business and industry, reuse and recycling, and buildings and land use.The Scottish government has implemented legislation with a target date of  for Scotland to achieve net-zero of all greenhouse gases – aiming to make a definitive contribution to climate change within one generation.Actions include decarbonisation of the public sector and engaging with business and industry, as well as encouraging iniduals to move towards low carbon living.Shetland’s carbon footprint is . tonnes of CO per capita, almost twice the national average of . tonnes. Shetland’s location, island transport links, industries and dispersed rural population, are all seen as contributing factors to this statistic.SIC environment and transport committee chairman Ryan Thomson said: “I’d urge folk to give us their views on how we can all work towards reducing Shetland’s carbon footprint.“This survey is the start of our ‘climate conversation’ and an open dialogue with the community, including local businesses, organisations and iniduals.“As we look ahead to recover from the pandemic, Shetland is well placed to support a greener recovery and we all need to play our part.”The online survey is open to all Shetland residents. It can be found at www.smartsurvey s SICClimateChange  and will be available for the next four weeks.In addition to completing the survey, anyone with particular comments can contact the council’s climate change strategy team by email on climatechange@shetland.gov.ukI’m shocked that we have double the national average. title: tributes paid to long serving brass band conductor
story: The long-serving music conductor of Lerwick Brass Band, Drew Robertson, has died aged .Drew first joined the band back in October , aged , having also played for the BB Flute Band and drums for Lerwick Pipe Band.Brass band secretary and historian Dougie Johnstone said that, in addition to trombone, Drew was able to play any other instrument in the band.He said: “Drew quickly became such a valuable band member that, by , he had been appointed assistant bandmaster.#When the position of conductor became vacant in the autumn of , Drew, with no formal training, took on the task.#On parade, no conductor being needed, he continued playing his trombone, or any instrument which was required.#Having worked in the Post Office, Drew decided to do some further education in his s and in - became a fully accredited music teacher, and was appointed a teacher of brass in the Lerwick and Brae schools.When bandmaster Bobby Burgoyne died in January  Drew was unanimously appointed his successor.He continued as bandmaster until  when, now , he retired from the organisational duties of the position. Hamish Nicol was appointed to succeed him, but Drew remained as musical director.Lerwick Brass Band, on its Facebook page, paid tribute to Drew as well as ex-bass trombonist Malcolm Browne, who has also died.The band stated: #We would like to pay our respects to Drew’s and Malcolm’s families at this very sad times.#What an astonishing career...One of the biggest crowds in recent years attended today#s Rembrance Sunday service and parade at the Lerwick War Memorial.The sun shone brightly today and Lerwick Brass Band played during a procession from the Market Cross in Lerwick to Mareel as the th ScreenplayA moving and reflective ceremony was held at the Lerwick War Memorial this morning to mark the th anniversary of the Battle of Britain. title: bells brae pupils assist in lerwick rewilding project
story: Lerwick Port Authority has scaled up its annual tree planting efforts to compensate for the Covid- impact which forced suspension of the initiative last year.Around  trees and shrubs donated by the authority have been planted on Tuesday at Holmsgarth Road by pupils from Bell’s Brae Primary School, currently involved in a “Living Things” project.The authority had participated since  in planting around  trees annually, within the grounds of Bell’s Brae and the new Anderson High School. This week the primary pupils moved on to rewilding an unused area of the port estate.Health, safety, environment and quality manager Stuart Wadley said: “With no planting last year because of Covid, we’ve upped the number of trees and shrubs donated.“It is an excellent, environmentally-friendly way for us to more-than-offset our usage of paper – usually the equivalent of  trees annually.“There are other benefits, including [that] it’s good for carbon capture, [which] will encourage wildle in a barren, grassed area, and reduce grass cutting and so use of fossil fuels.”Excited to support the project, the Bell’s Brae pupils know the benefits of tree planting and hope it will help the local environment.They stated: “Trees store carbon dioxide and help us to have cleaner air which is good for animals and us.”Most of the species planted are hardy and include native ieties that thrive in the Shetland climate, creating an attractive wooded habitat on the town’s outskirts, which will encourage pollinating bees and insects.The trees have been provided by the Shetland Amenity Trust and its woodlands team provided advice and support for the planting as part of the conservation and cultivation programme in the isles...Jim Tait is news editor at The Shetland Times.Harbour traffic statistics have again highlighted the severe impact of the pandemic – though bosses are working towards “better times ahead”.Da Voar Redd Up will go ahead next month, Shetland Amenity Trust has announced. title: consultation planned over network connections which could lead to new overhead lines
story: A series of online consultations will be carried out into plans by energy giant SSEN to provide connections for three windfarm projects.Sections of overhead line and underground cable are expected to help develop the new kV transmission network needed to link Energy Isles and Beaw Field windfarms in Yell and the Mossy Hill development west of Lerwick.As the electricity transmission network owner for the north of Scotland, SSEN Transmission says it is legally obliged to provide connections to electricity generators looking to connect to the network.But chairman of the Tingwall, Whiteness and Weisdale Community Council Andrew Archer says it is important the “least worst option” is adopted.Mr Archer, who  also chairs the Viking Community Liaison Group, said the move followed consultation last summer.“Our response to SSE then was that our first preference was for the cable to be buried, butthey refused to do that, then the route should avoid areas of domestic settlement.“I will be interested to seethere is now a proposed route.”As well as the cable, SSEN says a new switching station should help operate the Yell windfarms, while the company also hopes a subsea link will run to a new substation that will itself connect into the converter station at Kergord.Meanwhile, a new kV “grid supply point” substation should enable SSEN Distribution to transport the renewable energy to homes across the isles.The company is seeking feedback on its proposals, with virtual consultation events planned for st and nd June.Project manager Steven McMillan said: “We would like to thank those who responded to our earlier consultation in July last year, with the feedback received helping to shape the route and technology option proposals we are now presenting.“As a responsible developer, we are keen to continue to work closely with the local community to identity onshore and offshore routes for these new connections.“We encourage anyone who might be interested in our proposals to join the virtual consultations where you will be able to engage directly with our project team, via a live chat , to ask any questions you might have about the project and share feedback on the current proposals.”The virtual consultation is designed to be almost as interactive as face to face events.Let us just hope none fly to Shetland where they will meet the Viking Energy bird title: dunvegan show postponed due to covid
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineThe annual event, which celebrated its th anniversary in , boasts an assortment of attractions, activities and stalls for all the family, including stock competitions, a dog show, a tug of war, live music, a range of entertainment for children, and a wide iety of food and drink.The day provides a boost to the local economy, with people from all over Skye and beyond taking part in the bonanza, while the show is also a hit with visitors staying on the island from across the globe.On Monday, the decision was announced on the Dunvegan Show’s Facebook page following a meeting held by event organisers the Durinish and Bracadale Agricultural Association.: “With the uncertainty of Covid, and based on things we have heard from the Highland Council, we decided it would be best to postpone the show for another year.“I would say back in February therewere hopes that it might go ahead but the decision to postpone it for this year was unanimous.”He added: “There were a lot of people who didn’t attend the meeting, but I spoke to them in the weeks leading up to it and they all thought it was too dficult for it to go ahead – which is a shame.“I think the Portree show will be in the same boat, as will all the shows across the country.“It is very disappointing.” asked Mr Beatonthe association had any concerns over the availability of the venue for future shows given that Highland Council proposals to redevelop Dunvegan Primary School would include the current sports field land which is used for the event.He said: “At the moment the plans for the new school are looking to consolidate any community events, so once the new building is up and running we are hopeful that we will still have an area there and a location for the show.“But I’d imagine the issue going forward would be about building works. If they want to concentrate these during the summer holidays, then we might have to look for an alternative location for the showthere is too much work going on at the site.”

title: david gourley devoted student of ww1 history
story: Randalstown man David Gourley, who passed away earlier this month, will be remembered as a devoted student of World War One history and a champion of all those who served in that terrible conflict from across the political and religious ide. David, who conducted many battlefield tours to France and Flanders, was passionate about the social and military history of the war and the devastating impact it had on the entire island of Ireland.While his core interest lay with the men of the thDivision, David always stressed the often forgotten part played by Irishmen in units like the th and th Irish Divisions.His devotion to the entire subject and his tireless drive to inform modern generations of the war was reflected in the deep sense of loss felt by all who met him or worked with him on his many talks and projects.INSPIRATIONALDavid McCallion of the War Years Remembered museum said: “DavidGourley had a wealth of knowledge and was inspirational to many over the years through his talks and tours. “The thoughts, prayers and sincere condolences of all at WYR go to the entire Gourley family circle and friends. Stand down, rest easy your duty’s done and thank you for your dedication and service.”Jim McIlroy of the Ballymena based th Royal Irish Rles Association added: “David had a vast knowledge of the Great War and thousands of people benfited from his insight. At a personal level David was a friend, mentor and adviser to me and I will always be thankful for the times I spent with him both at home and on the Western Front. Thoughts and prayers are with Rita and the family circle. Come to me, all you who are weary and burdened, and I will give you rest. Matthew : Lest We Forget.”BallymenaEditor Des Blackadder who co-wrote the ‘Ballymena and the Great War’ website, said David Gourley was truly dedicated to his subject. “I had many conversations with David over the years. He was always finding a new angle to explore on the war’s history and those who enjoyed his battlefield tours will be saddened to hear of his passing.”May ,  peacefully at hospital. Dear husband of Rita, The Meadows, Randalstown and much loved father of Michael, David and Shauna, father in law of Keli, Pauline and Matt and precious granda of Stephanie, Leah, Lauren, David, Rebecca and Daniel.

title: mini land rover experience offered at glenarm castle
story: A brand new Mini Land Rover Experience, which lets kids take control of the driving seat, is gearing up to open at Glenarm Castle on st July. Supported by Charles Hurst Land Rover as the headline sponsor, complementing its current national “Outspiration” campaign, with additional support from NFU Mutual, the adventure will provide families with a safe, fun drive on the first off-road Mini Land Rover adventure course in Northern Ireland.Kids from -yrs can take over the wheel of one of  Mini Land Rover cars featuring steering wheel, a starter key, accelerator, lights, a direction switch with accompanying adults having access to a hand held fob which will remotely switch off the car.Reaching a top speed of potentially mph, kids will drive on a specically designed outdoor course with a range of ‘challenges’ along the way. The experience lasts  minutes which includes a  minute safety briefing. The Mini Land Rover Experience is part of a poundk investment, announced earlier this year, to signicantly enhance the Glenarm Castle vistor exerience. This includes sea view holiday pods, a Heritage Centre, Museum, Woodland Walk, E-Bike Hire, a Castle Shop and The Milk Parlour featuring ice cream using milk from N.Ireland’s only remaining Shorthorn dairy herd.  The investment has also helped to create up to  full and part time jobs.Looking forward to welcoming families to Glenarm Castle’s Mini Land Rover Experience, Adrian Morrow, Glenarm Castle Managing Director, said:“ We are very excited to offer the Mini Land Rover Experience as part of our visitor experience investment, sponsored by Charles Hurst Land Rover and supported by NFU Mutual, at Glenarm Castle. “We have taken great care to ensure that families have a fantastic, safe and enjoyable adventure. “ Kids will enjoy taking control of the wheel of the mini Land Rover cars and tackling the ‘challenges’ on our specically designed outdoor course. With many people choosing to holiday at home this summer, we are expecting the experience to be in high demand. “We would encourage anyone hoping to bring their family to enjoy the Mini Land Rover Experience to book in advance to avoid disappointment.”Alan Thompson, Head of Business at Charles Hurst Land Rover, said:“It’s been a reallydficult time for children, parents and families across Northern Ireland over the last year, so Charles Hurst Land Rover is delighted to be the headline sponsor for Glenarm Castle’s Mini Land Rover Experience to provide this fun, exciting and unique outdoor adventure experience for all the family this summer. “At Land Rover Belfast, we are passionate about the great outdoors and all the adventure that comes with it, so this partnership is a fantastic way to bring our ‘Outspiration’ campaign to le for families across Northern Ireland at a time when we have all spent so much time indoors. “If you’re looking for the ultimate family-friendly outdoors experience this summer, look no further than Glenarm Castle’s Mini Land Rover experience.”Ian Kernohan from NFU Mutual East Antrim Agency said:“ It’s great to see such a fun, exciting and dynamic attraction coming to Northern Ireland and there is no better setting for it than at Glenarm Estate.“NFU Mutual is delighted to support this unique attraction and no doubt it will be a huge success, bringing much needed enjoyment to local kids as we come out of lockdown and back to normality.” Booking for Glenarm Castle’s Mini Land Rover Experience is now open. The experience costs pound for  mins. Pre booking is advised. For further information and for booking details visit wwww.glenarmcastle. title: james and grace the most popular ni baby names for births registered in 2020
story: James and Grace the most popular NI baby names for births registered in James and Grace were the most popular first names given to babies in Northern Ireland, for births registered in .This is one of the findings of the Baby Names  statistics published today by the Northern Ireland Statistics and Research Agency. The Agency will also launch a new interactive baby names search tool later today which can be used to find out more information about the names registered.The statistics show Grace has held the top spot as the most popular girls’ name since , and has appeared in the top three most popular names for  consecutive years. James has been the most popular boys’ name for the past six years, and has ranked in the top five each year since reporting of baby names began in . In terms of boys’ names, Jackcomes second to James’ popularity, closely followed by Noah, which actually shared the top spot with James in  before falling to rd place in . Cillian and Finn joined the boys’ top  for the first time in . Within the boys’ top , the highest climbers in popularity between  and  were Senan, Kai and Brody. Some of the less common names given to baby boys in  were Bono, Bowie, Denzel, Jagger, Maverick, River, Rocky, Triumph and Wolfe.For baby girls, Grace has taken the top spot for the third year running, and this is the th consecutive year it has appeared in the top three. Emily remained the second most popular girls’ name in , holding this spot for the last three consecutive years, and Isla was in rd place.In , Fiadh entered the top  for the first time since the reporting of baby names began in . Within the girls’ top , the highest climbers in popularity between  and  were Arabella, Aoibheann, and Matilda.Compared with boys, a greater number of girls’ names have held the top spot since the reporting of first names began in . Some of the less common names given to baby girls in  were Dior, Divine, Ever, Harley-Quinn, Honor, Liberty, Nirvana, Porsche and Vogue.Birth registrations in  included  baby names that had not been used before. Blockbuster movies, popular television series, current celebrities and memorable places continue to appear to be influencing factors for some parents.Top  baby names in Northern Ireland, Boys: James –  Babies Jack –  Babies Noah –  Babies Charlie –  Babies Oliver – Babies Thomas –  Babies Finn –  Babies Theo –  Babies Cillian –  Babies Harry –  BabiesGirls: Grace –  Babies Emily –  Babies Isla –  Babies Fiadh –  Babies Olivia –  Babies Sophia –  Babies Sophie –  Babies Amelia –  Babies Lucy –  Babies Ella –  Babies and Freya -  Babies

title: northern ireland student faces four years in a camper van over dublin rent costs
story: It’s got all that I need, she says after accommodation proved unaffordableExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseSolution: Conni Dawson from Enniskillen, who plans to live in her camper van while she studies at UCD FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSolution: Conni Dawson from Enniskillen, who plans to live in her camper van while she studies at UCDMark BainTwitterEmailMay   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailThe cost of accommodation in Dublin has driven one student from Northern Ireland to come up with a unique approach to finding somewhere to live as she starts her four-year degree course at UCD.Conni Dawson , originally from Enniskillen, has decided the only option she has is to stay in a converted camper van.And while living in the camper van isn’t completely new to Conni, who has toured Ireland as a musician, she admitted she never thought she’d be making it her home for the next four years.“To be honest,I didn’t have it, I just wouldn’t be going to university,” said Conni, who is currently living in Co Clare on the west coast of Ireland and plans to start studying landscape architecture in September.Sky-high rentals in Dublin, her music career grinding to a halt through Covid and the lack of any additional student finance options meant it looked for a while as  Conni’s hopes of ing to her studies would have to be parked.“I just couldn’t afford it,” she said. “If I could get something for € or € a month I would rent, but it’s just not affordable, not on student money.”Read MoreNI housing market: How much your home is worthBut parking of a dferent nature could well have come to her rescue.“I originally got the van in February  with the idea of touring around Europe over the summer, but that never happened. I got stuck in Co Clare for Covid,” said Conni, who had been performing as a full-time harpist when the pandemic saw her ability to earn disappear overnight.“When it all happened we thought it would be a couple of weeks so I went there and figured it would be a nice place to hang out for a short while,” she said. “As it became more and more apparent that the music industry wasn’t going to be coming back in a hurry, I started looking at my other options and decided to go back to university.”While that may have seemed an easy decision to make, the reality of what she would be facing soon became apparent.“As I was at my parents’ home during Covid I’m not eligible for funding for university. If it wasn’t for the van then I just wouldn’t go as I’m not willing to take out a loan to pay for housing for four years.“I thought I have the van, why not  I can make this work.”Far from slumming it, Conni’s converted van comes equipped with a kitchen, living room and a bed.“It’s a big van. It’s kitted out with everything I need apart from a shower,” she said. “But I’m hoping to be able to use the facilities on campus at the university.”The only other obstacle is where to park it up when she is in the city.“The student’s union at UCD has already been in touch and will be trying to help arrange a parking permit,” she said.“That would be great. I’m hoping I can park there during the day and drive out and find somewhere to park it for the night.”She did admit to being wary of being branded as a ‘traveller’ though.“You don’t want people knocking on the door and asking you to move on,” she said.“I’ll try and be inconspicuous and not stay in any spot too long. title: covid expert gabriel scally calls for ventilation certificates in all northern irelandworkplaces
story: Each breath from an infected person contains roughly ml of air and , copies of the virusGetty Images FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueEach breath from an infected person contains roughly ml of air and , copies of the virusClaire McNeillyTwitterEmailMay   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailA leading Covid expert has called for ventilation certicates to be introduced in all workplaces here.Professor Gabriel Scally#s comments come as pubs, restaurants and cafes reopened for indoor hospitality on Monday.Dr Scally, a member of the independent Sage committee advising on the pandemic, said the standards of ventilation required in interior settings where people work should be made very clear and be based on updated knowledge of the virus.They should be legally enforceable and there should be an active inspectorate. The licenses should be dependent on their ventilation meeting the required standards, he said.Dr Scally added it was essential hospitality venues were regarded as workplaces because “it’s the workers in those places who’ll be exposed to risk for the longest period of time.He also said it needs to be monitored, “particularly for places that need licensing and need inspection already”.New research shows opening windows would dramatically cut the risk of Covid- transmission in indoor workplaces, most notably those which attend to the public.Health experts and scientists believe a ventilation certicate would see establishments quickly regaining patrons’ trust, as well as employees ing with confidence to other enclosed buildings such as offices and shops.At present one in every  people in the pub-going population is believed to have the virus.“People tend to be sitting opposite each other, around or across tables,” said Prof Scally.“Alcohol makes people more chatty, and conversations rise in volume. There can be laughter and enjoyment — that’s why we go to these places.“Unfortunately, that just generates more virus transmission into the airsomeone’s infected and the issue of ventilation then becomes extraordinarily important.”Meanwhile, Dr Alan Stout, BMA Northern Ireland GP Committee chair, said most indoor areas will already have carried out risk assessments over adequate air flow and ventilation.But he added: “There needs to be some sort of checks on indoor facilities as well, to make sure that is the case.”Architects have also been advised that in the post-pandemic era buildings should be designed with ventilation high on the list of priorities, which isn’t always the case in countries with mild climates.Dr Stout added the reopening of indoor hospitality here “shows that we are in a good position, both in terms of infection numbers and, critically, in terms of vaccinating people, but it’ll still need to be a managed environment”. He said discipline around face coverings would be essential to the success of bringing people back indoors.“When you’re sitting at a table with other people you’ll be eating and drinking, so you won’t have a mask on,” he said.“But when you get up to move around, wearing one is going to be very important. That’s where you protect and prevent the spread of everybody  in that environment.”The Department for the Economy, which has produced ventilation guidance, was asked to confirm who is responsible for ensuring and enforcing it in workplaces. A response had not been received at time of going to print. Credit: Steve ParsonsAdrian Rutherford and Lisa SmythMay   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailLess than a third of people in Northern Ireland plan to take a foreign holiday this year — despite the easing of restrictions on international travel from Monday.Almost half say they will wait until , while others intend to leave it even longer, according to a LucidTalk opinion poll for the Belfast .There is a notable age dference — with younger people more willing to head abroad in .But the overall findings will represent a blow for the travel industry, which had been banking on a summer dash to the airports as the Covid crisis eases.Read MoreYour questions about the new rules on travelling answered as Covid restrictions ease Overseas travel has been hit hard by the pandemic — apart from a short window last summer and at Christmas, people have been told they should only travel to or outside of Northern Ireland for essential purposes.But from today, a traffic light system for foreign travel will take effect.Twelve countries are on Northern Ireland’s ‘green list’, meaning travellers do not need to quarantine on their . Destinations include Portugal, Israel, Iceland, Australia and New Zealand.However, today’s poll reveals many are still deeply reluctant to hop on a plane abroad any time soon.People were asked, once vaccinated, when they would consider a foreign holiday.Just % said they plan to head away in  — % may travel this summer while another % would consider an overseas trip later in the year.The vast majority , said it would be next year before they think about going abroad.Another % said it would be two or three years before a trip outside the UK or Ireland, while % have no plans to go overseas at any point.The remaining % were unsure or had no firm opinion.Fewer older people are willing to consider overseas travel this year. Just % would consider doing so — % this summer and % at any point this year. More than halfsaid it would be next year before they consider jetting off, while % would leave it two or three years.By contrast, almost halfof  to  year olds are considering heading overseas this year — with % hoping to get away in the next few months and % later in the year. Another % will leave it to . Broken down by gender, males of any age are more willing to take a trip abroad — % plan to do so this summer and a further % will at some point in . Another % said it would be next year.However, just over a quarter of females plan to holiday abroad in  — % this summer and % this year. Some % plan to leave trips to .It comes as a public health expert from Belfast warned against summer holidays — despite the traffic light system for foreign travel.Professor Gabriel Scally told holidaymakers to “beware” and also warned it is “irresponsible” to travel to other countries while potentially infected with a dangerous iant.Prof Scally, a member of independent Sage, said: “The regional director of the World Health Organization in Europe issued a statement in the last couple of days saying there shouldn’t be international travel and I would agree with that.“It is undesirable to have people holidaying in international resorts at this time for all sorts of reasons.“It isn’t necessarily safe to travel on airplanes, there was a flight between India and Hong Kong and there were  infections and they were only picked up because of quarantine in Hong Kong.“Flights are dficult, but it isn’t just the flights, it’s what happens at arrivals and departures with queues of people in restricted spaces.“You also have lots of people from dferent countries mixing together at foreign resorts.“If you think back a year, the virus came to the UK and Republic of Ireland by people ing from holidays.”He continued: “It’s important to remember that the vaccine isn’t the cure all.“There’s always the risk posed by iants and it’s irresponsible to go off to another country and potentially take a dangerous iant with you.”Prof Scally also criticised the traffic light system, saying: “We need a proper managed quarantine system for everyone arriving into the country.”The Department of Health and the Executive were contacted for comment.Yesterday an airline industry chief said people who have received both doses of the Covid- vaccine should not face restrictions when travelling to countries on the Government’s amber list.Willie Walsh, director-general of airline body Iata, said people should be allowed to make up their own minds about the risks of travelling to amber list destinationsthey have received their jabs.Those ing from countries on the Government’s amber list must quarantine at home for  days and take pre-departure and post-arrival tests.But Mr Walsh, who is the former chief executive of IAG — the parent company of British Airways — said amber restrictions should be the same as those for green list countries for fully vaccinated passengers.He told the Mail on Sunday: “People were promised the benefit of being vaccinated — a vaccine idend — and they should be given it.“I thinkyou’ve had both shots then there’s no argument you can make to say those restrictions can remain in place, and people should be free to decide for themselvesthey see any risk in travelling to a green or amber country,” the former IAG chief executive added.Belfast Most Credit: Liam McBurney PAAndrew MaddenTwitterEmailMay   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailMore than half of people in Northern Ireland believe parents should have the right to refuse a Covid vaccine for their children, our poll shows.The news comes after Northern Ireland’s vaccine roll-out opened to those aged  to  and a raft of Covid restrictions are lted from Monday.“This has been made possible because of the success of the vaccination programme and the majority of people acting on the public health advice,” Health Minister Robin Swann said.According to the Belfast -LucidTalk poll, % of respondents felt parents should be able to refuse a vaccine for their children, while % felt they should not and % said they did not know, were not sure or had no opinion.The figures, however, y depending on the age and religious make-up of those who took part in the poll.Regarding  to  year-olds, a majorityfelt parents should not be able to turn down a vaccine for their children, while % felt they should and % didn’t know or had no opinion.Those aged  to , on the other hand, had starkly contrasting views. Some % said parents should be able to refuse a vaccine for their children and % said they should not. And % said they didn’t know, were unsure or had no opinion.Vaccines may be refused for a iety of reasons. For instance, earlier this year several countries temporarily halted the roll-out of the AstraZeneca jab due to concerns of rare blood clots.Due to evidence suggesting that younger people may be at greater risk of the extremely rare clots associated with the AstaZeneca vaccine, those in this age group can choose which vaccine to receive.The latest advice states that anyone under  can book a Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, or they can make what the Department of Health has described as an “informed decision” and get the AstraZeneca jab at Belfast’s SSE Arena or at participating community pharmacies.More than one million people in Northern Ireland have received a first dose of a Covid vaccine to date.Looking at the religious make-up of those who took part in the poll, it is apparent that Protestants are more likely to feel parents should have a say over vaccinating their children than when compared to Catholics.Some % of Protestant respondents felt this way, while % felt they should not have the right to turn down a jab for their children and % had no opinion, were not sure or didn’t know.Of those designating as Catholic, % felt they should have the right to turn down a vaccine for their children and % did not. The remaining % said they didn’t know or were unsure.In terms of those of no religion, % were in favour of parents having this right and % did not. Some % weren’t sure or had no opinion on the matter.On Sunday the Chief Medical Officer Dr Michael McBride urged everyone to get vaccinated. He said: “A Public Health England study has found the vaccines are highly effective. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueHealth Minister Robin SwannMay   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailA raft of new guidance around travel has been introduced in Northern Ireland.Anyone arriving here from the Common Travel Area and who plans to stay in Northern Ireland at least  hours must self-isolate for  days.Unless you are exempt.Read MoreHealth department forced to clary Swann’s wrong ‘unlawful’ amber travel blunder commentsPoll: % of Northern Ireland people plan holiday abroadExemptions include going to work, attending a medical facility or funeral, going to school, to access childcare or services to victims, fulfilling caring responsibilities, to look after an animal, to visit family and friends, go to court, and to provide emergency response services.If you do have to self-isolate, you’re allowed to leave self-isolation for a number of reasons, including to move to another place for self-isolation, to fulfil a legal obligation and to exercise with members of the same household.Under the guidance, householders of the person isolating aren’t expected to quarantine but should take extra care around the likes of hand washing and social distancing.Confused  You’re not the only one.It seems like even the health minister hasn’t got his head completely around the situation relating to travel.In a pre-recorded interview with Stephen Nolan on Monday morning, Robin Swann said travelling to an amber country for a summer holiday isn’t permitted.Before the interview had finished, the Department of Health had contacted the BBC to clary that Mr Swann was incorrect — travel to amber list countries isn’t recommended, but there is nothing to say people can’t do it.But is it such a surprise that Mr Swann got mixed up After all, it isn’t the first time there has been confusion over the public health advice in Northern Ireland.Throughout the pandemic, some of the restrictions have been laid down in law, while others, such as travel to amber countries, are only advice and guidance.Mr Swann might not want people to fly to Spain, Italy or France for a fortnight in the sun, and the experts might advise strongly against it, but that doesn’t mean people aren’t allowed.A traffic light system has been set up to allow some summer sun this year — but the lists of countries aren’t exactly easy to locate.Most of the countries on the green list require multiple flights and transfers to reach from Northern Ireland, while others have closed borders. You could be forgiven for thinking officials want to make travel as dficult as possible.At the same time, the UK and the Republic of Ireland have two dferent traffic light lists which are constantly in flux, depending on the changing landscape in dferent countries around the world.For example, currently anyone flying into the Republic of Ireland from Canada or the US has to stay in managed quarantine, whereas anyone arriving into England from both countries only has to isolate at home for -days.There’s no obvious reason for the disparity and it certainly adds to the whole confusion around foreign travel and what is and isn’t safe.The desire for some summer sun after a long, miserable lockdown in Northern Ireland is understandable — but a holiday is even more of a necessity after
